titleStmt.title: EMOTION REGULATION AND GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE 1 A conceptual framework for emotion regulation and global climate change solutions

affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychology, Swarthmore College, Swarthmore

analytic.title: EMOTION REGULATION AND GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE 1 A conceptual framework for emotion regulation and global climate change solutions

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: the climate change situation, we describe a precise conceptual and temporal framework that brings together two emotion-related cycles, climate change information, and climate change solutions. We suggest that climate change information prompts emotion generative processes that are prone to influence by emotion regulatory processes. Emotional and emotion-regulatory responses to climate change information may affect and be affected by beliefs, behavior, and systems. First, we apply a common theory of emotion regulation to the climate change situation.

Then, we review evidence for the use of climate change emotion regulation and expound the potential for emotion regulation to be involved with climate change solutions. Beliefs, behavior, and systems are conceptualized as climate change solutions. Belief is multidimensional (e.g., human causation and negative consequences), as is behavior (e.g., consumer behavior, decision making). Systems can include laws, regulations, infrastructure, and transportation; we highlight the importance of both social and physical systems. We close with suggestions for applying the framework, including experimental tests of emotion regulation.

div.head: A conceptual framework for emotion regulation and global climate change solutions
div.p: Earth's climate is changing in ways that threaten life, liberty, security, and wellbeing (1)(2)(3). Global climate change in this paper refers to anthropogenic (i.e., human-caused) climate change, which is in large part due to humans causing carbon dioxide and methane (i.e., fossil fuel emissions) to move from inside the Earth to the atmosphere (4). An indicator of this phenomenon could be extreme weather events occurring with greater intensity and frequency (e.g., cold and heat waves, wildfires, droughts, and floods, 5).

div.head: Mitigation of climate change depends on technological innovation and environmental
div.p: science, but also philosophy, behavioral science, economics, and other social sciences (6)(7)(8). The purpose of this perspective is to present a precise temporal and conceptual framework that brings together emotion generation and regulation processes, climate change information, and climate change solutions ( Figure 1). We start by applying an influential model of emotion generation and regulation, the extended process model (10), to individual responses to climate change information. Climate change emotions have been broadly defined as any "affective phenomena which are significantly related to the climate crisis" (11, p.1). In this framework, climate change emotions are elicited by situations (i.e., the World stage of emotion generation) in which features of the perceptible external environment or activated internal representations are related to climate change. We discuss ways in which emotion generation and regulation might promote or inhibit climate change solutions, including the roles of belief, behavior, and systems.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Conceptual Framework of Emotion Regulation and Climate Change Solutions Note. Climate emotions are initiated by exposure to climate change information. Emotion regulation affects emotion generation and both emotion and its regulation are bidirectionally associated with beliefs, behavior, and systems related to climate change. The black lines and arrowheads correspond to proposed paths in the conceptual framework. The box around emotion generation does not encompass the climate change information as there is an opportunity for emotion regulation via situation selection prior to exposure to (internal or external) climate change information. Each emotion regulation strategy targets the emotion generative cycle (the first valuation system initiated by an affective situation) and is subject to a second valuation system by which the need for emotion regulation is identified, a strategy is selected and implemented, and feedback occurs through monitoring.

div.head: Emotion Generation and Regulation
div.p: Emotions emerge from an emotion generation cycle that can be described as occurring in four stages: World (situation), Perception (attention), Valuation (appraisal), and Action (emotional response, 10). Each cycle is initiated by information about the climate change situation, and consists of four distinct processes that occur in temporal order, corresponding to the World (W), Perception (P), Valuation (V), and Action (A) stages (a WPVA cycle). The climate change information that initiates a given cycle can be externally-or internallyrepresented, which means that there need not be exposure to an external situation for climate change emotion generation to begin.

It is important to note that although physiological and psychological processes may play a role throughout each stage of the emotion generation cycle, subjective feelings are considered a prototypical component of emotion and tied directly to the Action (A) stage. Other historically prototypical components of emotion that occur in the WPVA cycles include appraisals of situations and expressive behavior (12). Each WPVA cycle of emotion generation can occur in a short period, so there may be many WPVA cycles that occur between exposure to climate change information and any behavioral outcome that could be considered a climate change solution.

Emotion regulation refers to processes that are responsible for altering emotion generation; emotion regulation strategies target different stages of the emotion generative cycle (10). Emotion regulation can be considered a second-level valuation system, which is often activated in response to and intended to modify the valuations of the first-level emotion generation valuation system. With that general goal, some emotion regulation strategies are intended to alter first-level valuation of situations without directly altering the first-level valuation process (i.e., alter a stage other than the V stage of the WPVA cycle itself). Emotion regulation also includes control-level processes (see the uppermost box in Figure 1) that monitor the success or failure of emotion regulation implementation, identify needs to regulate emotion, select strategies, and initiate implementation of strategies (13).

div.head: Climate Change and Emotion Regulation
div.p: Emotions can be regulated by targeting the situation itself or one of the four stages of the emotion generation process. At the front end, before emotion generation occurs, people might selectively engage with situations to shape emotional experience. For example, some studies on climate change report findings that could involve emotion regulation, such as selective engagement with climate change messaging based on emotional content (e.g., 14); situation selection could drive people to engage with funny climate change videos, compared to scary or informational videos.

Once in a situation, people can try to change the situation to change emotion-generative processes in many ways. One way is to change the external situation. Situation modification has been studied in laboratory tasks wherein people can modify affective stimuli (16), but also conceptualized as strategies to resolve or avoid interpersonal conflict (17). In the real world, one could implement situation modification on visual climate change information by changing the channel on a television when climate change information appears. Situation modification could be implemented interpersonally by avoiding talk about climate change with people who express conflicting beliefs on the topic. Importantly, situation modification targets only those situations which are external (10). The most research on emotion regulation and climate change involves the Valuation stage and cognitive change with cognitive reappraisal. This can also be considered the modification of internal situations. There are numerous aspects of appraisals that can be altered, such as the relevance, valence, likelihood, agency, and coping potential (24). One way to discuss cognitive change over longer periods of time (i.e., many WPVA cycles) is through the idea of coping with stressors (25). There is some research on coping with climate change among Swedish children (26,27). In a sample of children around years old, both meaningfocused coping (e.g., "I have faith in humanity; we can fix all problems") and problem-focused coping (e.g., "I talk with my family and friends about what one can do to help") were positively associated with self-reported pro-environmental behavior, while deemphasizing the problem (e.g., "Climate change is something positive because the summers will get warmer") had an inverse association with pro-environmental behavior (26). For high school students, greater problem-focused coping mediated the positive association between worry about climate change and pro-environmental behavior (27).

div.head: Links with Climate Change Solutions
div.p: Belief is one nonbehavioral aspect of climate change solutions, described as a precursor to emotion and emotion regulation, yet also subject to influence by emotion processes in the framework. Inat leastthe United States (31) Assessing behavior becomes even more complicated when the behavior is not limited to the individual. For example, individuals can engage in collective behavior, affect organizations through professional activities, and engage with political systems (8,37). While there are some social systems that explicitly embody individual behavior, such as social norms (e.g., 38,39), there are other social systems, such as laws and regulations, that are more distinguishable from individual behavior (e.g., 40). The conceptual framework proposed in Figure 1 does not predict how specific emotion regulation strategies might be associated with any specific climate change solution, only that the emotion generation and regulation processes causally separate climate change belief from behavior and systems, and that belief, behavior, and systems are all critical in climate change solutions.

div.head: Using the Framework to Guide Future Research
div.p: To move forward, we suggest that a guiding question could be "when and how is it helpful to change emotions?". This question can help to approach emotion regulation in the context of climate change solutions. This proposal is value-laden in the sense that it is framed to solve the problem of anthropogenic climate change. It requires that solutions measures be explicitly defined in relation to the problem of anthropogenic climate change. The validity of the question is contingent upon the science that suggests that there is problematic anthropogenic climate change.

One way to examine how and when an emotion regulation strategy is effective is with an experimental test of its effectiveness on a climate solution outcome, compared to a tight control condition. However, the context within which the climate change solution is conceptualized and operationalized is not guaranteed to be generalizable; as usual in psychological science, experimental control poses a risk to external validity. Studies must carefully consider the context and the climate solution measure, reporting methodological details with full transparency to allow for cumulative and reliable knowledge generation.

When deciding how to test emotion regulation, there are many strategies that people might be somewhat familiar with (e.g., inhibiting facial expressions), and participants could be instructed to use those strategies with relatively little training. For unfamiliar or difficult strategies, longer term training programs may be more suitable than brief instructions. For example, one study conceptualized emotion regulation as an outcome of psychological distance in construal level theory (i.e., spatially distant/proximate and cognitively abstract/concrete, 41).

Construal level theory (42) could be applied in future research by conceptualizing psychological distance as an emotion regulation strategy itself (43), or a particular tactic (e.g., a subset of a cognitive reappraisal techniques) targeting the Valuation stage of the emotion generative cycle (44).

When assessing the effect of emotion regulation, especially considering recent findings (30), it is important to consider when emotion regulation could be a problem. If downregulation of negative emotion reduces motivation to act, then even uninstructed emotion regulation could increase hedonic experience and at the same time, inhibit climate change solutions. It is important to understand the mechanisms (e.g., change in emotional experience) that might be responsible for the effects of emotion regulation. In the case of downregulating negativity, if the mechanism is more pleasant or less unpleasant experience, the mechanism itself may motivate further regulation. For mechanistic questions, causal hypotheses should be carefully constructed, as the proposed framework posits that multiple bidirectional associations could be at play. Physical systems may be more likely to affect emotion processes than be affected by the same processes. Physical systems (e.g., public transportation) are slow to change and often require change in social systems as an impetus. Even social systems (e.g., carbon taxes) are slow to change, compared to behavioral outcomes like recycling or reducing consumption, as well as even faster behavioral outcomes like financial decision making. Emotion regulation could play a critical role in the changes to social physical systems, but it would be important to design studies with extended temporal aims to obtain empirical evidence for such a claim.

For one example, any urban population has a large range of financial resources and accessibility issues. The optimal emotion regulation processes are likely different for people who experience different effects of climate change and have different resources to cope with the situation. For another example, people who have experienced recent, catastrophic natural disasters linked to climate change may need to reduce stress and downregulate negative emotion, whereas people who are more insulated from the effects of climate change could potentially benefit from upregulation of negative feelings about climate change.

div.head: Concluding Comment
div.p: Affective science has much to contribute when it comes to understanding complex responses to climate change informationincluding decisions and actions taken by individuals throughout society. In this review, we primarily focused on how emotion regulation processes could affect climate change solutions, which is a relatively unstudied topic. Multiple emotionregulatory goals, such as hedonic (a desire for pleasantness) and functional (a desire for either more or less emotion to achieve an outcome) are essential to consider in responses to climate information. It would be especially important to know if the hedonic success of emotion regulation has inadvertently disarmed our collective ability to address the very real threat of climate change. The precise conceptual and temporal framework of emotion regulation and climate change solutions proposed here can inform future research around the globe and help people think through their own and others' responses to climate change information.

figure.figDesc: Abstract (# words: 250) Scientists have established consensus that humans are changing Earth's climate and that the changes imminently threaten life, liberty, security, and wellbeing. Recent reviews describe emotion as a central component in human responses to climate change information, including decisions and actions that could be involved with climate change mitigation. Despite the burgeoning body of work on emotions related to climate change, scientists have only begun to understand how people experience and manage those emotional responses, and the consequences of emotion regulation. To guide and encourage work on emotion regulation and

Climate change mitigation often refers to the reduction of future effects of humans on global warming but in this paper is not distinguished from adaptation, the alleviation of inevitable consequences or unavoidable effects of climate change. Although the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) emphasized the importance of social sciences in climate change mitigation in the contribution of IPCC 2022 working group III (see Box TS.11, 7), affective processes and other social science solutions have been less common targets in climate change mitigation and adaptation, compared to technological and environmental solutions (9).

After exposure to a situation is the Perception stage. The Perception stage of emotion generation occurs when people think about climate change (i.e., an internal situation) or when there is sensory input or narrative, such as in the processing of visual or semantic information (for examples of information, see 19-22). Thus, examples of emotion regulation that target this stage include distraction and rumination. There are extensive studies of distraction (e.g., avoiding the topic) and engagement with (e.g., talking about) climate change (15,23), but it is not clear that distraction and engagement were in the service of emotional change (i.e., attentional deployment emotion regulation strategies).

Similar to meaning-focused and problem-focused coping, there have been positive associations between self-reported tendencies to use cognitive reappraisal (not specific to climate change) and pro-environmental behavior (28,29). On the other hand, there is some evidence of null effects of experimentally manipulated cognitive reappraisal on conservation behavior, and that effectively reducing negative feelings about the threat of climate change on biodiversity (i.e., to bumblebees) without a focus on problem-solving was associated with reduced conservation intentions (30). These studies suggest that there are multiple ways that reappraisal could be associated with climate solutionswhile habitual use of cognitive reappraisal may be a positive sign for individuals in general, cognitive change at any moment may have positive, negative, or no consequences. Finally, in contrast to strategies that target antecedents of an emotional response, response modulation targets the motivational Action stage itselfexperience, expression, or physiology (10). After appraisals have elicited a response, modulating an emotional response to climate change at the Action stage could involve repressing feelings of doom, or hiding a frown when encountering information about climate change that conflicts with current beliefs. To our knowledge, there have been no studies of emotion regulation that target the Action stage of emotion generation.

and Australia (32), there is evidence that individual differences in climate change beliefs or perceptions are associated with climate change emotions. Moreover, in two previous cross-sectional studies, self-reported habitual cognitive reappraisal was associated greater perceptions of climate change (i.e., beliefs) and climate change perceptions mediated the association between cognitive reappraisal and selfreported pro-environmental behavior in Italy (28). These cross-sectional data raise interesting questions about the causal direction of the association between cognitive reappraisal and climate change beliefs. On the one hand, belief could affect emotion regulation. People who experience positive emotions when contributing to climate change solutions could be motivated to upregulate positive emotions through further action (33), which seems unlikely to occur for people who do not believe in climate change. On the other hand, a change in belief might be considered a type of cognitive change when used to regulate climate emotion. For example, incongruence between what we want (e.g., fossil fuels) and what we know (e.g., fossil fuels are causing climate change) could lead to resolution of negative emotion through denial of climate change occurrence (34). Thinking about the relative stability of beliefs in climate change (e.g., 35), emotion regulation might be more likely to influence belief in the long term, over many emotion cycles, compared to a shorter time period, or fewer cycles. If coping, as described previously, involves many WPVA cycles, changing beliefs to regulate emotion over time could be described as coping. Like beliefs, both behavior and systems can affect and be affected by emotional processes. When emotional processes cause behavior and systems to change in such a way that people have adapted to or mitigated climate change, that can be considered a climate change solution. Behavioral and systems levels of climate change solutions are fundamentally dependent on one another, considering the social nature of humans and the dependency of modern civilization on group and collective organization.For example, the systems defined by the framework are human systems and humans implement systems through behavior. Behavior can be operationalized at the group or the individual. A group-level behavior could be the enactment of a law that establishes carbon taxes as a measure to affect systems to solve the climate change problem. An individual behavior could be similarly classified as pro-environmental by thinking about the intention of or motivation for the behavior, such as desires to mitigate climate change, protect biodiversity, or to be more sustainable. There is an empirical gap between self-reported pro-environmental behavior and an individual's impact on the environment(36). When studying systems or behavior, assessing the impact of ostensibly pro-environmental outcomes is a high priority.

Although future causal hypotheses could test the effects of emotion regulation on individual behavior, change must also occur at systems levels(45). Thus far, we referred to systems as norms, laws, and regulations that are solutions to human-caused climate change, but systems might also include collectives, organizations, institutions, and more. Future work could consider the emotion regulation processes in anger consensus messaging(46), democratic pragmatism (47), or even genuinely collective emotion(48). Social systems are complex, and much work is needed to understand how emotion regulation could promote climate change mitigation in people and groups.For example, future studies should consider how the associations between emotion regulation and climate change solutions differ among political or occupational groups. When exposed to dire climate change messaging, one may reappraise the urgency of climate change as less urgent if one's chosen political partytheir political teamclaims that there is no urgency. Across Europe, there were weaker associations between belief and worry related to climate change among those with right-leaning political ideologies, compared to those with leftleaning ideologies(49). It is important to think about unique roles tied to occupations, including but not limited to farmers who make decisions about natural resource use, consumer habits of salaried employees living in cities, corporate executives whose decisions impact large organizations, and people who have influence on executive, judicial, and legislative systems such as politicians, judges, and lobbyists.Despite the importance of ideology and occupation, we speculate that for emotion regulation, physical systems might be even more relevant. The effects of climate change, the information available about climate change, and the ability to enact climate change solutions are all dependent on physical systems such as geography, infrastructure, and financial resources.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Thank you to M. Alexandra Kredlow and Holly A. Taylor for feedback on this framework and the manuscript.
